Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Kevin P. Klubek of the University of Rochester to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at the Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials (FUNSOM), Soochow University in Suzhou, Jiangsu, China. The project title is "Blue Emitters for Organic Light-Emitting Diodes." The host scientist is Professor Liang-Sheng Liao.

Organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) are a new technology being developed for display (replacing liquid crystal and plasma technologies) and solid state lighting applications (replacing incandescent and fluorescent lighting). OLEDs contain several layers of organic (carbon based materials) thin films sandwiched between two electrodes. When a battery is connected to the electrodes, a current passes into the organic materials and one of the layers emits light. Depending on molecular structure, the organic materials can emit red, green or blue light, and all three colors are needed for most applications. While OLEDs have an ability to achieve high brightness with low power consumption, blue emitting OLEDs have a significantly shorter lifetime (time for the initial brightness to decrease by 50%) than red or green emitting OLEDs. The research shown in this work compares various blue emitting materials in an effort to understand how molecular structure impacts device performance, notably that of device lifetime.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the research effort between Soochow University and the University of Rochester (UR) will lay the foundation for forging a strong ongoing relationship as these universities have many shared interests that extend beyond the OLED field. One of the key goals is to widely distribute the scientific and technological understanding that is achieved by publishing in peer reviewed journals and presenting at conferences. Furthermore, the Fellow will give a presentation outlining his research to the host university and a comparable presentation on the collaboration with the Tang lab and his stay in China on return to his home institution. Both presentations will promote the importance and benefits of the NSF EAPSI fellowship.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic Light-Emitting Diodes (OLEDs) were first invented by Tang and VanSlyke in 1987. Since then, OLEDs have received tremendous attention in the past two decades and have recently become commercially viable for displays and solid-state lighting applications. OLEDs have advantages of being thin, lightweight, energy efficient, and flexible (when using flexible substrate). While red and green OLEDs have high efficiency and excellent lifetime (t50=time for initial luminance to decrease by 50%), blue OLEDs have high efficiency and inferior lifetime (Table 1). In fact, the blue lifetime is an order of magnitude lower compared to red and green OLEDs.

Table 1: Performance data of R,G,B phosphorescent OLEDs (PHOLED) from Universal Display Corporation (www.udcoled.com)

Bis(4,6-difluorophenyl-pyridinato-N,C2) picolinate iridium (III) (FIrpic) (Fig. 1) is a commonly used blue phosphorescent dopant. While this dopant has been used to achieve high efficiency OLEDs, there are few reports on lifetime and those that do report t50 < 100 hrs.  It has been reported that the F atoms and picolinate ligand may contribute to the instability of the molecule.

Since FIrpic based devices have such poor stability, it is important to look at phosphorescent dopants that have pronounced different molecular structures. OLED devices using Ir(dmp)3 [fac-tris[3-(2,6-dimethylphenyl)-7-methylimidazol[1,2-f]phenanthridine] Iridium(III)] and Ir(iprpmi)3 [fac-tris[(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-2-phenyl-1H-imidazol[e]iridium(III)] (Fig 1)have been reported, although devices were not optimized for efficiency and lifetime. These two materials lack the picolinate ligand and F substituents that are present on FIrpic, and possess imidizole as the key functional group on the ligand. Material properties (highest occupied/lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals, absorption/emission spectra, etc.) have not been reported for either of these dopants.

In this project, we purchased Ir(iprpmi)3 and obtained important material properties including 1) photoluminescence and absorption spectra for both film and solution, 2) electrochemical redox data, and 3) ultraviolet photoelectron spectra (UPS). Since Ir(dmp)3 is not commercially available, we attempted a multi-step synthsis to obtain this material. Unfortunately, we were unsuccessful in producing enough of this material to fully characterize it.  Efforts are ongoing to complete the synthesis.

Once Ir(dmp)3 is synthesized and characterized, both dopants will be tested ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Organic Light-Emitting Diodes (OLEDs) were first invented by Tang and VanSlyke in 1987. Since then, OLEDs have received tremendous attention in the past two decades and have recently become commercially viable for displays and solid-state lighting applications. OLEDs have advantages of being thin, lightweight, energy efficient, and flexible (when using flexible substrate). While red and green OLEDs have high efficiency and excellent lifetime (t50=time for initial luminance to decrease by 50%), blue OLEDs have high efficiency and inferior lifetime (Table 1). In fact, the blue lifetime is an order of magnitude lower compared to red and green OLEDs. Table 1: Performance data of R,G,B phosphorescent OLEDs (PHOLED) from Universal Display Corporation (www.udcoled.com) PHOLED Performance (brightness 1000 cd/m2) 1931 CIE color coordinates Efficiency (cd/A) Device Lifetime t50 (hours) RED (0.66,0.34) 29 600,000 GREEN (0.31,0.63) 85 400,000 LIGHT BLUE (0.18,0.42) 50 20,000 Bis(4,6-difluorophenyl-pyridinato-N,C2) picolinate iridium (III) (FIrpic) (Fig. 1) is a commonly used blue phosphorescent dopant. While this dopant has been used to achieve high efficiency OLEDs, there are few reports on lifetime and those that do report t50 < 100 hrs. It has been reported that the F atoms and picolinate ligand may contribute to the instability of the molecule. Since FIrpic based devices have such poor stability, it is important to look at phosphorescent dopants that have pronounced different molecular structures. OLED devices using Ir(dmp)3 [fac-tris[3-(2,6-dimethylphenyl)-7-methylimidazol[1,2-f]phenanthridine] Iridium(III)] and Ir(iprpmi)3 [fac-tris[(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-2-phenyl-1H-imidazol[e]iridium(III)] (Fig 1)have been reported, although devices were not optimized for efficiency and lifetime. These two materials lack the picolinate ligand and F substituents that are present on FIrpic, and possess imidizole as the key functional group on the ligand. Material properties (highest occupied/lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals, absorption/emission spectra, etc.) have not been reported for either of these dopants. In this project, we purchased Ir(iprpmi)3 and obtained important material properties including 1) photoluminescence and absorption spectra for both film and solution, 2) electrochemical redox data, and 3) ultraviolet photoelectron spectra (UPS). Since Ir(dmp)3 is not commercially available, we attempted a multi-step synthsis to obtain this material. Unfortunately, we were unsuccessful in producing enough of this material to fully characterize it. Efforts are ongoing to complete the synthesis. Once Ir(dmp)3 is synthesized and characterized, both dopants will be tested in various OLED device architectures and compared with each other along with the commonly utilized phosphorescent dopant Firpic in an effort to understand how the molecular structure of the dopant affects device performance. In addition to the research accomplishments discussed above, this EAPSI program resulted in many cultural exchanges and discussions between myself and my Chinese colleagues comparing the USA and China, with topics including local and regional cuisines, housing types and expenses, transportation, and general finance. Differences in work and family life, along with the roles and responsibilities of those in industrial and academic settings were also discussed at length. Furthermore, I was able to give a presentation to my Chinese Host group on the types of research being conducted at the University of Rochester and I was also able to attend many group meetings presented by my Chinese colleagues. I also presented a poster at the EAPSI in China 10th year celebration/4th China-US Young Scientist Forum while also attending various presentations and discussions centered on American/Chinese points of view on topics such mentoring and networking, work/life balanc...
